item.title: French police officer and partner murdered in 'odious terrorist attack'
item.description:
Convicted terrorist Larossi Abballa fatally stabbed couple in front of their son and posted video of attack on Facebook

The French government has denounced an “abject act of terrorism” after a man with a previous terrorist conviction carried out a gruesome knife murder of a police commander and his partner at their home outside Paris in the presence of their three-year-old son.

Larossi Abballa, a Frenchman previously convicted of taking part in a jihadi recruitment network and claiming allegiance to Islamic State, posted a video of the fatal attack on Facebook Live.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Angelique Chrisafis in Paris and Kim Willsher in Magnanville

item.title: Emotional Barry Steenkamp says Pistorius must pay for Reeva's murder
item.description:
Reeva Steenkamp’s bereaved father tells hearing he and wife have forgiven athlete but he must still face sentence

The father of Reeva Steenkamp told a crowded courtroom on Tuesday that although he had forgiven Oscar Pistorius, who was convicted of his daughter’s 2013 murder, the former athlete should pay for what he has done.

In emotional testimony in the Gauteng high court in Pretoria on the second day of a sentencing hearing, Barry Steenkamp described how his family had been devastated by the killing of the law graduate and model.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jason Burke in Pretoria

item.title: Orlando gunman Omar Mateen 'was a regular at Pulse nightclub'
item.description:
Customers had seen killer there before and several report getting messages from him on gay dating apps

The gunman who killed 49 people in an attack on a gay nightclub in Orlando is said to have been a regular at the venue and had messaged several people on gay dating apps, according to reports.

An unnamed FBI official told the Associated Press on Tuesday that the bureau was investigating the claims.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ed Pilkington in Orlando and Jessica Elgot

item.title: French labour law protests again descend into violence
item.description:
Police clash with demonstrators in Paris as strikes close Eiffel Tower and disrupt transport links during Euro 2016

Several hundred masked protesters have hurled objects at police in Paris, as the latest demonstration against disputed changes to France’s labour laws descended into violence.

The clashes erupted on Tuesday as the international spotlight was turned on France as the host of the Euro 2016, which have also been marred by violence between rival football fans.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Agence France-Presse in Paris

item.title: Thousands of children travelling alone from Africa to Europe, says Unicef
item.description:
UN agency says nine out of 10 refugee and migrant children seeking help in Europe via Italy are unaccompanied, and warns they face ‘appalling’ risks

More than nine out of 10 refugee and migrant children arriving in Europe through Italy this year are travelling alone, the UN children’s agency, Unicef, said on Tuesday, warning of the “appalling” risks children face while escaping conflict and poverty.

Related: Safe memories hard to find for children traumatised by escape to Europe

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Thomson Reuters Foundation, part of the Guardian development network

item.title: May marks one more record hot month for the world
item.description:
May was the fifth record warm month this year, upping the odds that 2016 will be the hottest year on record, reports Climate Central

The streak continues: May was record warm for the globe, according to NASA data released Monday.

It’s now even more likely that 2016 will be the hottest year ever recorded, despite the demise of one of the strongest El Niños on record.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Andrea Thompson for Climate Central, part of the Guardian Environment Network

item.title: Orthodox Christians' global gathering unravels as five churches pull out
item.description:
After 55 years of planning, the historic holy and great council of 14 Orthodox churches in Crete may collapse over power struggle

After an interlude of more than a millennium, 55 years of careful planning, and within days of its opening, the first global gathering of Orthodox churches since the year 787 is teetering on the brink of collapse amid dissent and power struggles.

The historic “holy and great council” of the world’s 14 self-governing Orthodox churches, due to begin in Crete on Sunday, may not go ahead after five pulled out.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Harriet Sherwood Religion correspondent

item.title: Operation Puerto blood bags must be released to authorities, judge orders
item.description:
• Madrid court finds Wada and the UCI should be given access
• Ruling follows successful appeal against decision to destroy bags

One of the sport’s biggest doping scandals is in the spotlight again with the release to authorities of 211 bags of frozen blood belonging to leading athletes from cycling, athletics, football and other sports.

An appeal court in Madrid ruled on Tuesday that the 211 blood bags found in the fridge and freezer of Eufemiano Fuentes, the Spanish medic known as “Doctor Blood”, should be handed over to laboratories in Spain, Italy and elsewhere.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Giles Tremlett in Madrid

item.title: Millions of animal 'trophies' exported across borders, figures show
item.description:
At least 200,000 of the nearly 2m trophies collected from animal hunts were endangered species, according to report revealing the scale of the industry

Around 1.7m animal “trophies” have been exported across borders by hunters in the last decade, with at least 200,000 of them endangered species, according to a new report.

US hunters are by far the largest killers of trophy animals, including half of all the 11,000 lions shot in the last decade, the report found. The issue came to global attention in July 2015, after a US dentist paid more than $50,000 to kill a lion called Cecil, who was being tracked by conservation scientists.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Damian Carrington

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi undergoes heart surgery
item.description:
Surgeons at Milan’s San Raffaele hospital spend about four hours replacing former PM’s faulty aortic valve

Silvio Berlusconi has been placed in intensive care following a heart operation. Italy’s former premier was admitted to hospital this month with a life-threatening condition.

Surgeons at San Raffaele hospital in Milan spent about four hours on Tuesday replacing Berlusconi’s faulty aortic valve, and he was then moved to the coronary care unit to recover. Hospital staff did not immediately give further detail of his condition or how long he would stay at San Raffaele.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Rosie Scammell in Rome

item.title: Revealed: first mammal species wiped out by human-induced climate change
item.description:
Exclusive: scientists find no trace of the Bramble Cay melomys, a small rodent that was the only mammal endemic to Great Barrier Reef

Human-caused climate change appears to have driven the Great Barrier Reef’s only endemic mammal species into the history books, with the Bramble Cay melomys, a small rodent that lives on a tiny island in the eastern Torres Strait, being completely wiped-out from its only known location.

It is also the first recorded extinction of a mammal anywhere in the world thought to be primarily due to human-caused climate change.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Michael Slezak

item.title: Gay man sues Chinese psychiatric hospital over 'sexuality correction'
item.description:
Yu Hu, 32, claims staff at Henan hospital held him forcibly and tried to ‘cure’ his homosexuality with medicine and abuse

A gay man from northern China is suing a psychiatric hospital he alleges attempted to “cure” him of homosexuality with drugs, confinement and beatings.

The 32-year-old, who uses the assumed name Yu Hu, claims he was held against his will at the Zhumadian No 2 People’s hospital in Henan province in October last year. There, he was forced to undergo what doctors called “sexuality correction therapy”.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Tom Phillips in Beijing

item.title: Academics urge Rouhani to speak out over house arrests of Iranian critics
item.description:
Seventy scholars sign letter imploring president to intervene in cases of Mir Hossein Mousavi, Zahra Rahnavard and Mehdi Karroubi

Seventy distinguished academics from North American universities have urged the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, to break his silence over the ongoing house arrests of the country’s opposition leaders.

In a letter written on the seventh anniversary of the disputed 2009 presidential election, the signatories asked Rouhani to use his position as the highest elected official in Iran to speak out about the plight of Mir Hossein Mousavi, his wife Zahra Rahnavard and Mehdi Karroubi.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Saeed Kamali Dehghan

item.title: Indonesia planning mass executions after Ramadan
item.description:
Spokesman for attorney-general confirms that executions are set to resume after a hiatus

Indonesia plans to put 16 convicts to death after next month’s Muslim Eid holiday, an official said Tuesday, confirming executions were set to resume after a hiatus.

The death row convicts will be executed “immediately after” the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, Mohammad Rum, a spokesman for the attorney-general’s office, told AFP, but he did not give a precise date.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Agence France-Presse

item.title: Carbon dioxide levels in atmosphere forecast to shatter milestone
item.description:
Scientists warn that global warming target will be overshot within two decades, as annual concentrations of CO2 set to pass 400 parts per million in 2016

Atmospheric concentrations of CO2 will shatter the symbolic barrier of 400 parts per million (ppm) this year and will not fall below it our in our lifetimes, according to a new Met Office study.

Carbon dioxide measurements at the Mauna Loa observatory in Hawaii are forecast to soar by a record 3.1ppm this year – up from an annual average of 2.1ppm – due in large part to the cyclical El Niño weather event in the Pacific, the paper says.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Arthur Neslen

item.title: Dutch woman held in Qatar after rape claim to be deported
item.description:
The 22-year-old was given a one-year suspended sentence, while man accused of attacking her was sentenced to 140 lashes

A Dutch woman who spent three months in custody in Qatar after reporting that she was raped is to be deported having been found guilty of adultery.

The 22-year-old from Utrecht was given a one-year prison sentence by a Qatari court, suspended for three years. She was not present at the hearing. The woman was fined 3,000 riyal (£600).

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Gordon Darroch in The Hague and agencies

item.title: Canadian hostage Robert Hall killed by militants, Philippines confirms
item.description:
President Benigno Aquino announces Abu Sayyaf has murdered a second hostage from group abducted on the island of Samal in September 2015

The Philippines has confirmed Canadian hostage Robert Hall was killed by Islamist militants.

“We strongly condemn the brutal and senseless murder of Mr Robert Hall, a Canadian national, after being held captive by the Abu Sayyaf group in Sulu for the past nine months,” said Benigno Aquino, the Philippines president.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ashifa Kassam in Toronto

item.title: Legal ivory sale drove dramatic increase in elephant poaching, study shows
item.description:
Research shows the legal sale in 2008 catastrophically backfired – but two African nations want to repeat the stockpile sell-off

A huge legal sale of ivory intended to cut elephant poaching instead catastrophically backfired by dramatically increasing elephant deaths, according to new research.

The revelation comes just months before a decision on whether to permit another legal sale and against a backdrop of more African elephants being killed for ivory than are being born. In 2015 alone, 20,000 elephants were illegally killed.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Damian Carrington

item.title: Traffickers exploiting young refugees in French camps, says Unicef
item.description:
Report says children have been subjected to sexual violence, and open letter calls on UK to act more quickly

Young people in refugee camps in Calais and Dunkirk are being sexually exploited and forced to commit crimes by traffickers, according to a Unicef report.

The document, which draws on six months of interviews and is due to be published on Thursday, paints a disturbing picture of the abuse of unaccompanied minors in camps in northern France. It says children are being subjected to sexual violence by traffickers who promise passage to the UK.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Karen McVeigh

item.title: Warning after four people killed in bear attacks in Japan
item.description:
The separate attacks in Akita prefecture over three weeks may be act of one bear which has got used to human flesh says local vet

People in northern Japan have been warned to stay away from mountain forests after four people were killed in a spate of bear attacks, amid a dramatic rise in the number of bear sightings.

Police in Akita prefecture found the body of a woman they suspect was mauled by a bear in a mountain forest at the weekend. The victim, Tsuwa Suzuki, 74, suffered injuries so horrific that local authorities were initially unable to identify her.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Shari Town Local Government/AFP/Getty Images
Photograph: Shari Town Local Government/AFP/Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Justin McCurry in Tokyo

item.title: Italian dies in wingsuit accident on Mont Blanc
item.description:
A 33-year-old found dead 2000m up in the French Alps after attempting a wingsuit jump, mountain rescue services said

An Italian man has been found dead on Mont Blanc in the French Alps after attempting a wingsuit jump, one of the most dangerous extreme sports, mountain rescue services said.

The 33-year-old was reported missing on Saturday and found at an altitude of 2,000 metres on Sunday after several hours of search efforts.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Agence France-Presse

item.title: UN criticises UK for spending aid money on for-profit private schools
item.description:
Report accuses government of increasing inequalities in developing countries by financing academies at the expense of state schools

The UK’s role in funding for-profit private schools in the developing world has come under attack by the UN, which fears the spike in private, “low-fee” schools in poor countries could undermine the sustainable development goal of inclusive and equitable education for all by 2030.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Oliver Balch

item.title: French police killer seemed calm before attack, says mosque rector
item.description:
Cleric says Larossi Abballa was engrossed in reading the Qur’an at mosque in Mantes-la-Jolie hours earlier

Hours before killing two French police officers in front of their three-year-old son, Larossi Abballa was in his local mosque reading the Qur’an.

Mohammed Droussi, a rector at the mosque, said Abballa, who has a previous conviction for terrorism, had been so engrossed in his religious study after attending midday prayers that he had to ask Abballa to leave as the prayer room was closing.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Kim Willsher in Paris

item.title: ‘The Eurosceptics’ Little England is a claustrophobic timewarp’ – why I’m glad to be a European
item.description:
The late Hugo Young wrote powerfully in praise of the EU following the introduction of the euro in 1999. His arguments about national identity, Brussels bureaucracy and the fantasies of anti-Europe Tories are more relevant than ever in today’s Brexit debate

Hugo Young, who wrote a twice-weekly column in the Guardian from the time he joined the paper in 1984 until his death in 2003, is widely considered one of the greatest British political journalists of the modern era. Eloquent, judicious, authoritative and profoundly moral, he was an indefatigable critic of Margaret Thatcher and an equally passionate pro-European.

His final book, This Blessed Plot, published in 1998, ruthlessly dissected what he saw as the failure of successive British leaders to guide the country to its destiny at the heart of Europe. In this essay, published the following year before the launch of the euro, Young explains his journey from “Euro-agnostic” to European.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Murdo Macleod for the Guardian
Photograph: Murdo Macleod for the Guardian

item.dc:creator: Hugo Young

item.title: Euro 2016: opening weekend violence between England and Russia fans – video explainer
item.description:
Russia has been fined €150,000 (£130,000) and given a suspended disqualification from Euro 2016 because of violence between supporters after England’s 1-1 draw with Russia on Saturday. Six England supporters have been arrested and about 50 Russians deported. England manager Roy Hodgson pleads with fans to avoid trouble before their match with Wales on Thursday

  • Russia handed suspended Euro 2016 disqualification and lash out at England
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: ​North Korea shuts model village that 'reminds Kim Jong-un of executed uncle' ​
item.description:
‘Mini Pyongyang’ attraction once managed by Jang Song-thaek is to be dismantled, according to South Korean sources

North Korea has closed a model village in Pyongyang because it reminds leader Kim Jong-un of his executed uncle who managed the project, media reports said on Tuesday.

Pyongyang Folk Village, which features miniature versions of the capital’s buildings, was completed in 2012, with Kim describing it as the brainchild of his deceased father Kim Jong-il.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: AFP

item.title: The last 'sworn virgin' of Montenegro
item.description:
Fears for health of survivor of traditional practice that allowed women without brothers to live as men and inherit property

An unusual practice has stubbornly endured in remote villages in the Balkans since medieval times. Traditionally, if the head of a household in this strongly patriarchal society died without a male heir, one of his daughters could choose to become a man.

She would dress like a man. She was permitted to smoke and mingle with men in the village cafe. She could even carry a weapon.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Gordana Knezevic for RFE/RL, part of the New East network

item.title: Old rivals, new threats: Zimbabwe's politicians ready themselves for Mugabe's death
item.description:
Political atmosphere is becoming increasingly turbulent as potential leaders fight to reinvent themselves, reports the Daily Maverick

To the casual observer, nothing much seems to have happened in Zimbabwe in recent years: Robert Mugabe, the world’s oldest head of state, remains president and Zanu-PF is still the ruling party more than 35 years after it took power.

But there has, in fact, been a tectonic shift. Like Zimbabwean society itself the opposition has become deeply fractured and any meaningful cooperation between the multitude of opposition parties seems unlikely. Moreover, this fragmentation has affected Zanu-PF itself – and that’s a big deal.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Stuart Doran for the Daily Maverick, part of the Guardian Africa network

item.title: Readers' prize winning pictures of life in Russia
item.description:
With ten signed copies of Luke Harding’s book A Very Expensive Poison to give away we asked you to share your favourite photo of life in Russia. Here are the pictures that were selected in our prize draw

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian readers

item.title: Russian artist Petr Pavlensky: 'I saw the machine from the inside'
item.description:
Jailed for setting fire to Moscow’s security HQ, performer says he’ll continue ‘testing the limits’ of political art. RFE/RL reports

Controversial Russian political artist Pyotr Pavlensky was released this week after spending seven months in prison for setting fire to the door of the Federal Security Service in Moscow.

He was convicted of damaging a cultural monument but, contrary to fears that he would be given a harsh jail term, was sentenced with a fine of about £5,500. As the judge finished reading the sentence on Wednesday, the courtroom erupted in applause. Speaking outside the courthouse the artist thanked his supporters and said: “It does not matter how the trial ended. What is important is the fact that we were able to unmask, uncover the truth: the government is founded on the methods of terror.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Dmitry Volchek for RFE/RL, part of the New East network

item.title: Does Makoko Floating School's collapse threaten the whole slum's future?
item.description:
Multiple award-winning Makoko Floating School was a beacon of hope in this Lagos slum until its collapse this week. Now some fear the whole area and its 300,000 residents are at renewed risk of being cleared out for redevelopment

Like most Lagos residents, I was familiar with Makoko Floating School. Its steep, three-storey triangular roof was visible from the Third Mainland Bridge, which cuts dramatically across the Makoko lagoon, the city’s vast waterworld slum. Designed by the Nigerian architect Kunlé Adeyemi, the Floating School was the winner of multiple awards for architecture and urbanism, attracting great international attention and acclaim.

But I had never actually been up close until yesterday, when I approached in a rickety wooden canoe piloted by a young man in a burgundy T-shirt and grungy shorts.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Okoroafor

item.title: Controversial film on Sergei Magnitsky’s death set for US screening
item.description:
Russian lawyer’s supporters say documentary is ‘full of lies’ and is an attempt to undermine White House sanctions. RFE/RL reports

А film about Sergei Magnitsky, the Russian lawyer who died in prison after allegedly being tortured, is set to be shown in Washington after criticism and legal threats forced European TV channels to pull their broadcasts.

The private screening at the Newseum, scheduled for the 13 June, will be the latest skirmish in a battle over Magnitsky’s legacy, whose death led to the US launching sanctions against a host of Russian officials.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Mike Eckel for RFE/RL, part of the New East network

item.title: Freed Ukrainian pilot calls for talks with separatist rebels
item.description:
Nadiya Savchenko offers to negotiate with insurgency leaders as skirmishes continue with little prospect of lasting solution

Nadiya Savchenko, the Ukrainian helicopter pilot who spent more than a year in a Russian jail, has issued a surprise call for direct dialogue with the self-proclaimed Donetsk and Luhansk “people’s republics”.

Savchenko was sentenced to 22 years in jail in March but released as part of a prisoner swap last month. She returned to Kiev a hero and has taken up the parliamentary seat she was given while jailed.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Shaun Walker Moscow correspondent

item.title: A day at the Miss Dairymaid contest in Belarus - in pictures
item.description:
At an annual contest showcasing local workers, photographer Siarhiej Lieskiec found Soviet traditions celebrated with a modern twist. The Calvert Journal reports

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Siarhiej Lieskiec for the Guardian
Photograph: Siarhiej Lieskiec for the Guardian

item.dc:creator: Siarhiej Lieskiec for The Calvert Journal, part of the New East network

item.title: Hawa Golakai: the Liberian scientist turned cult crime writer
item.description:
As her novel is published in the UK, the author explains why she’s tired of simple African stereotypes – both on the page and off

Hawa Jande Golakai is, by some standards, an unlikely literary sensation. A Liberian clinical immunologist turned crime writer, she says she’s usually annoyed by the genre.

“So often the detective is a man and the woman is his lovely wife who the detective goes home to. We are just the background noise,” she says as her debut novel, The Lazarus Effect, is published outside of Africa for the first time.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: China's Bordeaux: winemakers in 'gold rush' to turn desert into vineyards
item.description:
International wine giants and the super-rich are ploughing their fortunes into an arid corner of Ningxia region

“This,” says Emma Gao as she races through the sun-scorched countryside of north-west China in a dusty Nissan Livina, “is la Route des Chateaux.”

“There are almost 40 different entrepreneurs – maybe more. Every day it is changing,” the Chinese winemaker explains, slaloming between French, English and Mandarin as she tours her 70-hectare (170-acre) vineyard at the heart of a region government officials are calling China’s Bordeaux.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Tom Phillips for the Guardian
Photograph: Tom Phillips for the Guardian

item.dc:creator: Tom Phillips in Helan county, Ningxia province

item.title: Zane Gbangbola inquest: mother warned not to return to home
item.description:
Nicole Lawler informed ‘Health Protection Agency had identified small pockets of hydrogen cyanide’ at property, coroner told

The mother of a seven-year-old boy who is believed to have died after breathing toxic fumes at their home in Surrey during severe flooding was warned not to return to the property because cyanide gas had been found, an inquest has heard.

Just hours after Zane Gbangbola was pronounced dead in hospital, his mother, Nicole Lawler, was informed by medics that the “Health Protection Agency had identified small pockets of hydrogen cyanide at the home”, she read aloud from her medical notes.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Caroline Davies

item.title: Tom Watson: EU freedom of movement may need reform
item.description:
Jeremy Corbyn’s deputy appears to go further than Labour leader in suggesting changes to immigration rules should be considered

Labour’s deputy leader, Tom Watson, has said the EU’s rules allowing free movement of people across the bloc may need to be reformed because of concerns about high levels of immigration.

The senior Labour MP told the BBC that the issue was complicated, but that the EU may have to accept there is a need for change.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Rowena Mason Political correspondent

item.title: Obama angrily rejects Trump's Muslim ban: 'Do Republicans agree?' – live
item.description:
• Democratic primary takes place today in Washington DC
  • Guns, terror, and LGBT rights: Orlando raises stakes for next president
  • Trump bans Washington Post from officially covering his campaign

6.10pm BST

In an email to supporters this afternoon, Vermont senator Bernie Sanders told his fans that although “the voting is done” after today’s primary in Washington DC, “our political revolution continues” - and previewed his online video address on Thursday night, in which it is speculated that he will suspend his campaign.

“When we started this campaign, I told you that I was running not to oppose any man or woman, but to propose new and far-reaching policies to deal with the crises of our time,” Sanders wrote. “And for the past fourteen months, through the entire primary process, we’ve sent the establishment a message they can’t ignore: we won’t settle for the status quo.”

6.01pm BST

This is the angriest members of the press have seen President Barack Obama in a long time.

"That's not the America we want." Here are 3 key minutes from the president's remarks... https://t.co/Ky01ePTH8Z

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Scott Bixby in New York

item.title: Mexico's fans at Copa América have two messages: viva El Tri, and dump Trump
item.description:
Mexico matches on American soil are special affairs, and ahead of Monday night’s tilt against Venezuela the US’s most passionate fanbase let its voice be heard

Donald Trump is making a campaign stop in Houston on Friday. He was already in the city on Monday in fright-mask form, courtesy of Sergio Pérez, one of several Mexican fans at the team’s Copa América match against Venezuela who made their feelings clear about the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.

“Trump right now, everybody doesn’t like him,” Pérez said, his voice muffled from behind the rubber mask. He posed for pictures next to a unicorn, a clown and a man holding a placard that said: “Trump I brought my birth certificate just in case. #FuckTrump.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Tom Dart in Houston

item.title: Facebook apologises for displaying Philippine flag upside down
item.description:
The social network promoted a banner with the red portion on top, which normally indicates the country is at war

Facebook has apologised for featuring an inverted Philippine flag to mark the country’s independence day on 12 June.

The social network greeted users in the Philippines on Sunday with the message: “Happy Independence Day! Here’s to all of the Philippines’ health, happiness and prosperity.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Associated Press

item.title: More Australians seeking treatment for alcohol consumption than any other drug
item.description:
Amphetamine treatment rises to 20% of the 114,912 people aged 10 and older who received treatment for drug use

About one in 200 Australians sought treatment for drug use in 2014–15, with alcohol the main drug people needed help with, a new report from the Australian Institute for Health and Welfare launched on Wednesday shows.

In 2014–15, there were 114,912 people aged 10 and older who received treatment for drug use from the 843 treatment agencies across Australia that provided the institute with data. Between them, the clients received 170,367 treatment episodes over the year, with treatments within a facility lasting an average of 22 days.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Melissa Davey

item.title: Gay and voting for Trump after Orlando: how the right is eyeing the LGBT vote
item.description:
In the aftermath of Orlando, conservatives are facing the dilemma of deflecting attention from their own homophobic history – and drawing voters to the right

The worst mass shooting in American history comes in the midst of a frenzied culture war. In North Carolina, a legislative battle is unfolding over who exactly should be permitted to use which bathroom stall. Many on the Christian right are still reeling over the supreme court’s decision a year ago to compel the states to allow gay marriages, something they see as trampling on their religious liberty.

In the aftermath of Orlando, hard-edged religious conservatives are facing a dilemma. How can they call for a redoubled assault on “radical Islam” without drawing attention to their own homophobic history?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jason Wilson

item.title: Kissing my girlfriend at the Zodiac: gay bars are everything straight people take for granted
item.description:
Arwa Mahdawi reflects on these sanctuaries that are like therapeutic spaces that patch up invisible wounds and provide unconditional acceptance

It took me a long time to work up the confidence to be seen with Ellen. It was 2001; we were 18, students at Oxford. We went to the Zodiac, a grungy straight club in town. We danced awkwardly and then kissed awkwardly. My first gay kiss in a public place. Seconds later, another milestone: my first homophobic assault. A girl grabbed me, shoved me, made a gagging gesture, her face ugly with hate. I left the club immediately, gone was the confidence I’d had when I’d walked in. I felt ashamed.

Related: Tell us: what does your local gay bar mean to you?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Arwa Mahdawi

item.title: International Albinism Awareness Day – in pictures
item.description:
Event, which takes place every 13 June, aims to increase understanding of condition and fight superstition, discrimination and stigma

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Matt Fidler

item.title: Physio games: how rehab is coming to a screen near you
item.description:
NHS trust trials software developed by a Romanian company to rehabilitate patients using interactive and therapeutic games

For anyone who has spent months recovering from a shoulder injury, car accident or stroke, physiotherapy can be a slow and painful healing process. It also relies on a lot of repetitive exercises that can bore even the most self-disciplined of patients.

Cosmin Mihaiu, a 26-year-old Romanian who co-founded of Mira Rehab, knows this well, having broken his arm falling from a tree aged seven and then struggling through six weeks in a cast followed by six weeks of physiotherapy.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Kit Gillet in Bucharest

item.title: 'Oscar Pistorius has to pay for what he did,' Barry Steenkamp tells sentencing hearing – as it happened
item.description:
Live coverage of the second day of sentencing hearing in which Pistorius could face 15 years in prison for murder of Reeva Steenkamp in 2013

1.28pm BST

Oscar has to pay for what he did. He has to pay for it …

That is up to the court. And we will go by the decision that the court hands down to Oscar. But he has to pay for his crime.

But I hear her crying at night. I hear her talking to Reeva. She feels just as much as I do.

1.04pm BST

Nel says he has another, final witness to argue in aggravation of sentence but would like to complete that testimony in one day – so would rather wait until tomorrow.

He says he does not want to take a chance of the evidence carrying overnight.

It will be emotional evidence, I don’t want to do that to the witness.

Nel: I’m just doing the best I can for my witnesses … My only concern is I don’t want to keep the witness overnight.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Claire Phipps

item.title: Tell us what you love about Europe
item.description:
Whether it’s Spanish beaches, the northern lights in Iceland or a cappuccino we’d like to hear about the European things you love

Europe has given us a lot - and in celebration of one of the smallest continents in the world we’d like to hear about all the everyday European things you love.

Whether it’s spaghetti bolognese, the siesta or French beer show us your photos of all things European. Whether they are things that you consume in the UK that come from a European country or what you love most when you visit abroad, share your pictures and stories with us.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian readers

item.title: Oscar Pistorius must pay for murder of Reeva Steenkamp, says her father – video
item.description:
Testifying on the second day of Oscar Pistorius’s sentencing hearing at the high court in Pretoria on Tuesday, Barry Steenkamp says his wife June has forgiven the Olympic runner for the murder of their daughter Reeva

  • Oscar Pistorius sentencing: Barry Steenkamp says ‘world should see wounds inflicted on Reeva’ – live
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: The next UN secretary general: meet the candidates - Guardian Live
item.description:
Three of the people standing for UN secretary general present their vision for ‘the world’s most impossible job’

Mark Rice-Oxley is joined by António Guterres, former Portuguese prime minister and until recently the United Nations high commissioner for refugees; Vuk Jeremić, Serbia’s former minister of foreign affairs and former president of the United Nations general assembly; and Igor Lukšić, Montenegro’s former deputy prime minister and foreign minister. The event is introduced by UNA-UK’s executive director, Natalie Samarasinghe.

The UN security council will pick its preferred candidate later in the summer.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chaired by Mark Rice-Oxley, audio produced by Stuart Silver

item.title: Pope Francis rejects donation from Argentinian president with 666 in sum
item.description:
Centre-right leader Mauricio Macri gave 16,666,000 pesos to educational foundation backed by pope, reports say

The frosty relationship between two of the world’s most prominent Argentinians appears to have taken a turn for the worse after it emerged that Pope Francis rejected a charitable donation from president Mauricio Macri – at least partly – because the sum included the figure 666.

Earlier this month, the centre-right president made a donation that totaled 16,666,000 pesos (slightly under $1.2m) from the Argentinian government to the Scholas Occurentes educational foundation, which is backed by the pope and is based on a similar organization founded by Francis when he was cardinal of Buenos Aires.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Uki Goñi in Buenos Aires

item.title: French police chief and partner killed in stabbing claimed by Isis
item.description:
Convicted terrorist stabs commander to death outside home in Magnanville before taking partner and son hostage

President François Hollande has convened crisis talks after a man convicted for terrorist offences and claiming allegiance to the Islamic State stabbed a French police commander to death in front of his house outside Paris, then killed his partner who also worked for the police.

The 42-year-old police commander was in plain clothes when he was stabbed to death as he arrived home at around 8.30pm on Monday night in a quiet residential area of Magnanville, north-west of Paris.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Angelique Chrisafis in Paris

item.title: What has the EU ever done for my … wanderlust?
item.description:
About 2 million Britons have made use of the right of EU citizens to live in another member country. A leave vote would mean an uncertain future for them

From retirees on the Spanish coasts to young professionals in Dublin, Berlin and Bratislava, Britons have taken to EU freedom of movement with enthusiasm. Any EU citizen can move to another member state for three months and stay indefinitely if they can prove they have resources to live on.

The government estimates that 2 million Britons have moved to another EU country, although the UN puts the number at only 1.3 million. Spain is the most popular destination, followed by Ireland and France. Britons abroad are wealthier than those at home, although in 2015 a small proportion of about 30,000 were claiming benefits.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Rankin

item.title: 'It's so beautiful': Indigenous rangers spot rare golden-coloured mole in desert
item.description:
Rarely seen and barely studied, the kakarratul, or northern marsupial mole, spends most of its life burrowing through sand dunes

A little golden creature darted across a dirt track in the Gibson desert, just in front of the four-wheel drive.

Pintupi woman Yalti Napaltjari, travelling with a group of Aboriginal rangers from the Kiwirrkurra Indigenous protected area, gave a yell and jumped out.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Central Desert Native Title Services
Photograph: Central Desert Native Title Services

item.dc:creator: Calla Wahlquist

item.title: French police commander and partner killed in possible Isis-linked attack – video
item.description:
A 42-year-old police commander has been stabbed to death in front of his home, in the Paris suburb of Magnanville, the French interior ministry has confirmed. The incident, which ended in a hostage situation that also left the attacker and a woman – thought to be the police commander’s partner – dead, took place on Monday and was dealt with by French elite police units. The attacker claimed allegiance to Islamic State during the stand-off, according to one source. A young boy was also found at the property and was rescued unharmed

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Prosecutions follow cockfighting event – archive, 14 June 1938
item.description:
14 June 1938: It became illegal in the middle of the last century, but it is certain that it has never been entirely suppressed in this country


Both Cumberland and Lancashire may be reckoned as counties with strongly developed sporting inclinations, but the “county cockfight” which was the subject of yesterday’s prosecution was not an event that brings credit to the North.

Not that any special barbarity need be assumed for regions north of the Trent because the birds in this case came from Lancashire and Cumberland and the fighting was done in Westmorland; there have been cases in Hampshire, and it was a parson writing from a Radnorshire rectory who last year had a letter to the press in which cockfighting was described on historical grounds as “ever the most democratic of national pastimes.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Canada's First Nations suicide emergency: Trudeau meets chief for crisis talks
item.description:
Chief Bruce Shisheesh of the Attawapiskat First Nation says community of 2000 is struggling after more than 100 suicide attempts

The chief of the northern Canadian community of Attawapiskat First Nation has met with Canada’s prime minister for the first time, hoping to hammer out solutions to a suicide crisis that has gripped his community.

“It was a start,” Chief Bruce Shisheesh told the Guardian after he sat down with Justin Trudeau in Ottawa. “I’m still concerned, though. We’re still struggling.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ashifa Kassam

item.title: Pakistani clerics issue fatwa against 'honour' killings
item.description:
Council of influential Sunni clerics condemns the killing of women who marry men of their choosing as a ‘great sin’

An influential group of Pakistani clerics have issued a fatwa against “honour” killings, with a spokesman calling them “unethical and unjustifiable” following a series of attacks on women that have caused national outrage.

The Sunni Ittehad Council (SIC) said on Monday that killings such as last week’s murder of teenager Zeenat Bibi in Lahore after she married the man of her choice were a “great sin”.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Agence France-Presse

item.title: Russia will not attend historic meeting of world's Orthodox churches
item.description:
Moscow Patriarchate bishop suggested postponing discussion of differences, the first in more than a millennium, because other churches won’t participate

The Russian Orthodox church has said it will not attend a historic meeting of all of the world’s Orthodox churches because other churches have walked out.

The meeting on the Greek island of Crete due to start on Sunday would be the first in more than a millennium.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Associated Press in Moscow

item.title: Fugitive capybara captured in Toronto park 19 days after zoo escape
item.description:
One of two rodents, who became social media celebrities after escaping less than a day after they arrived at High Park zoo, was lured into a metal cage

For 19 days, the renegades roamed through a forested Toronto park, munching on grass and frolicking in ponds while social media celebrated them as folk heroes.

But the brief taste of freedom has come to an abrupt end for one of the capybaras that escaped last month from a Toronto zoo. The dog-sized rodent – native to South America and resembling a large, tailless beaver with stumpy legs – was lured into a metal cage on Sunday evening in one corner of a 400-acre park in the city.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ashifa Kassam in Toronto

item.title: Convoy to Calais will be a show of solidarity with refugees | Letters
item.description:
The refugee crisis is escalating in what has been described as the biggest humanitarian crisis since the second world war (Young refugees sexually exploited by traffickers, 13 June). Governments across Europe are failing to accept responsibility as thousands are drowning in the Mediterranean, fleeing desperate situations at great risk to seek sanctuary. Instead of addressing the issues, fences and detention centres are being built and as a result of the EU-Turkey deal people are being deported to war zones where their homes and lives have been destroyed.

The Tory government is ramping up racist rhetoric as it shifts the blame on to immigrants and refugees for the problems caused by its own austerity measures. In a show of callousness it voted against an amendment to the immigration bill which would have allowed 3,000 unaccompanied Syrian children entry to the UK. Despite this it was forced into a U-turn. However, this hard-won amendment offering possible sanctuary to child refugees is not enough. We need to know how many will be offered refuge and when to see if real good will be done.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Antonio Olmos for the Observer
Photograph: Antonio Olmos for the Observer

item.dc:creator: Letters

item.title: 'His spirit seems broken': Pistorius severely depressed, court told
item.description:
Clinical psychologist, called by defence in sentence hearing, says ex-athlete needs to be in hospital, not back in prison

Silent, head bowed, shoulders hunched in an ill-fitting suit, Oscar Pistorius would have attracted little attention from a casual observer unaware of his central role in the drama under way on Monday, in a nondescript ground floor courtroom in Pretoria.

Behind him sat members of his own family and that of Reeva Steenkamp, the model and law graduate he killed on Valentine’s Day 2013, by firing four shots through a door in his home only a few miles away. In front was his defence team, who hope this week to convince judge Thokozile Masipa, to be lenient, as well as the state prosecutors, there to demand the minimum 15-year prison sentence for the double-amputee Olympic runner, after his original manslaughter conviction was changed to murder.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jason Burke in Pretoria

item.title: Killings of LGBT and HIV-affected people rose 20% in 2015, report finds
item.description:
• NCAVP finds 24 reported hate violence homicides in 2015
  • Mass shooting in Orlando alone would double that tally for 2016

Homicides of LGBT and HIV-affected people in the US have risen 20% since 2014, according to a report released on Monday.

Related: Orlando shooting: attacker appeared to be self-radicalized, says Obama – live

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Mona Chalabi, Guardian US data editor

item.title: The New Yorkers who live exclusively via Airbnb: 'Home is where the Wi-Fi is' – video
item.description:
When David Roberts and Elaine Kuok moved to New York City, they couldn’t decide where to live – so they packed everything into three suitcases and lived solely on Airbnb. A year and a half later, they’re still doing it. Could digital sharing make having a home obsolete?

  • The men who live in Tokyo’s internet cafes: ‘It’s a home, by the hour’ – video
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jess Gormley, Tom Silverstone, Bastien Inzaurralde, Noah Payne-Frank, Greg Pittard and Chris Michael

item.title: How nature turned a failed communist plan into Bucharest's unique urban park
item.description:
The wild wetland of Văcărești is a symbol of nature’s resilience. Without human interference, wildlife has reconquered this abandoned lake and transformed it into a green oasis in the middle of one of Europe’s densest cities

There are rarely ever more than a handful of people present when you visit Văcărești, Bucharest’s wild wetland just a 30-minute stroll from the city centre. Almost no one dares go down into the park itself; the perimeter wall – a five-metre concrete embankment that isolates this unique green space from the surrounding city – remains the favourite and safest spot.

From an unfinished piece of urban water infrastructure abandoned in 1989, Văcărești has been reconquered by nature and wildlife without any human intervention, to become one of Romania’s most diverse ecosystems. Last month, following a four-year campaign led by a small but determined group of environmental activists, the government finally granted it protected area status, officially making 183-hectare Văcărești one of the biggest urban nature parks in Europe.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Justinien Tribillon

item.title: An insider's guide to Bangalore: the chilled out Silicon Valley of India
item.description:
Decorated bulls, foaming lakes and a massive IT boom – it’s no wonder software engineers are also rock musicians in the city also known as Bengaluru

Our motto: swalpa adjust maadi.*

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Deepa Bhasthi

item.title: The people who live in Tokyo's net cafes: 'It's a home, by the hour' – video
item.description:
In Tokyo, commutes are so long, and apartments so small, that some people sleep in internet cafes such as i Cafe Akibaplace – which provides showers, meals, clothes and everything else you might need for a substitute home. We kick off our series on the revolution in urban living by spending a night inside Japan’s ‘homes by the hour’

  • The British Pavilion at the Venice Biennale
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chris Michael, Jess Gormley, Yusuke Uchijima, Tom Silverstone, Noah Payne-Frank and Keiko Tanaka

item.title: Can 'smart' birdhouses help improve air quality in Amsterdam?
item.description:
City links: From behaviour-changing Wi-Fi in the trees to Jarvis Cocker as the voice of Sheffield’s trams, we round up the best city stories from this week

The best city stories from around the world this week take us from the Dutch capital to Mexico City as we think about air pollution, vertiginous living and Jarvis Cocker. Share your thoughts about these city stories – and any others you’ve seen – in the comments below.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Francesca Perry

item.title: Hundreds of sheep roam through Spanish city – video
item.description:
Police video footage shows hundreds of sheep walking through Martínez de Velasco avenue in the city of Huesca in north-east Spain. Local authorities say the herd escaped while the shepherd was sleeping. Police managed to return the flock safely

  • Monkeys who shop: Guardian Cities’ favourite urban animals stories
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Old v new architecture – your pictures of incongruous city buildings
item.description:
New developments, and the historic buildings they dwarf, can look out of place as the cityscape evolves. Our readers shared their pictures of the conflict between old and new in cities around the world – from Aberdeen to Zagreb

Manchester's tallest building, and the highest. at 169m tall, in the UK outside London, towers over the reconstructed Roman Fort in Castlefield.

Sent via GuardianWitness

By buryboy

23 May 2016, 13:57

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian readers and Francesca Perry

item.title: From 'guard cats' to monkeys who shop: our favourite urban animal stories
item.description:
More than two years after the launch of Guardian Cities, it seems high time for a round-up of all the animal-related stories that have kept us amused along the way. Here’s our top 10 – now tell us yours

  • Hundreds of sheep invade city in Spain

Four feral cats, named after the original Ghostbusters, are being “employed” in a Chicago brewery to guard the grain from rats. In exchange, they are paid a daily rate in the only currency they understand: dry cat food.

As Medill Reports Chicago explains, the owners of the Empirical brewery in Chicago decided to employ these cats, rather than pest control companies, because they are both cheaper and, to quote verbatim, “adorable”.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chris Michael

item.title: This brutalist world: from Rotterdam's 'vertical city' to Tokyo's capsule tower – in pictures
item.description:
Peter Chadwick’s new book collates some striking examples of this enduringly popular architectural genre – from the infamous to the virtually unknown

  • This Brutal World is published by Phaidon
Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Courtesy University of California, San Diego
Photograph: Courtesy University of California, San Diego

item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Key Latin American human rights group faces serious funding crisis
item.description:
Support for human rights in South America and Caribbean under threat, which could reduce scrutiny of press freedom, political violence and indigenous rights

In late 2014, the Mexican government asked a group of experts from the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) to provide technical assistance with its investigation into an attack on 43 students from the Ayotzinapa teacher training school. The experts delivered two devastating reports, which dismantled the government’s official investigation – especially its insistence that the students’ bodies had been burned in a funeral pyre.

For families of the students – farmers from impoverished Guerrero state – the IACHR’s intervention offered the opportunity to keep alive a case causing enormous embarrassment for the image-conscious government. The IACHR also “provided a complete picture of the shortcomings in the Mexican justice system”, says Santiago Aguirre, deputy director of the Miguel Agustin Pro Juarez Human Rights Centre, which worked with the students’ families.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David Agren in Mexico City

item.title: Rapid urbanisation in Africa, and the cost of conflict and terrorism
item.description:
More than half of Africans could live in cities by 2050, but how will this affect development? Plus, this year’s global peace index

If you are viewing this on the web and would prefer to get it in your inbox every two weeks, register for the email edition

With more than half of all Africans expected to live in cities by 2050, can rapid urbanisation act as a catalyst for development and growth? The latest African Economic Outlook says it is possible, but only if authorities prioritise inclusive growth, jobs, better housing and social safety nets, and improve links with rural areas. “To seize this ‘urbanisation dividend’, a number of bold policy reforms are necessary,” the report says.

Conflict and terrorism cost the global economy $13.6tn (£9.3tn) last year, according to the global peace index. It rated Syria as the least peaceful county, followed by South Sudan and Iraq. Iceland, Denmark, Austria and New Zealand were among the world’s most peaceful countries.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Burundi turns to WhatsApp as political turmoil brings media blackout
item.description:
Threats and harassment have driven journalists into exile, leaving social media to fill the void for those wanting to reach the world and connect disparate groups

Burundi’s year-long crisis has not gone away. It started with President Pierre Nkurunziza’s determination to claim a third term, trampling over the constitutional arrangements that ended a decade-long civil war.

Press freedom is a major casualty of the new strife; but the turmoil has also transformed the way in which Burundians get information. For better or worse, social media has filled the vacuum left by the shutting down of the most popular radio stations and forcing out of many of the country’s professional journalists.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Thierry Vircoulon

item.title: Poor nutrition now affects a third of the human race, says report
item.description:
Being malnourished is the new normal, expert warns, as global nutrition report reveals heavy toll of poor diet, from stunting to diabetes

Malnutrition has become “the new normal” and now affects a third of humanity, according to a study that warns of the devastating human and economic toll of undernutrition and obesity.

The 2016 global nutrition report says the world is not doing enough to tackle a worldwide epidemic that is leaving more and more people suffering from diet-related conditions such as stunting, anaemia, heart disease and diabetes.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones

item.title: Safe memories hard to find for children traumatised by escape to Europe
item.description:
At Ritsona camp in Greece, refugee children are encouraged to play and draw as part of efforts to provide relief from the anxieties of their uncertain lives

Inside a cylindrical white tent at the Ritsona camp, children who have seen too much try to learn how to be young again. Every day, about 40 children, many of whom have survived perilous journeys to reach southern Europe, come to this safe space, set up by the Spanish Red Cross, to draw, play and let off steam.

Today, they are learning about hygiene. A volunteer teaches the basics at a whiteboard as children perch on stools. Their drawings are strung across the tent’s ceiling.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Ross in Athens

item.title: Everything you need to know about UK aid and the 0.7% spending pledge
item.description:
As parliament debates a petition to drop the foreign aid spending commitment, we explain the target and look at how the UK compares to other donors

On Monday, MPs will, yet again, debate the UK’s commitment to spend 0.7% of national income as international aid each year. The debate was triggered by an online petition that received more than 230,000 signatures. Launched by the Mail on Sunday, it called on the government to drop the spending commitment and “provide money only for truly deserving causes, on a case-by-case basis”. In response to the petition, UK NGOs have rallied around the Twitter hashtag #ProudofAid.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Claire Provost

item.title: India counts the cost of trying to solve its drinking problem
item.description:
Campaigners say alcohol abuse fuels violence towards women and girls in India. But how would the state cope without funds from liquor sales?

By the time the liquor store on Kalavasah Teni road in the south Indian city of Madurai opens for business at 10am on Monday, a small queue of regular customers has already begun to form outside.

Within minutes, bottles fly off the shelves. By the end of the day, the shop will have sold about 600 bottles of alcohol and made about 100,000 rupees (£1,000). On bank holidays or during religious festivals, sales can be 10 times that amount.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Vidhi Doshi in Madurai

item.title: A nice cup of tea … and other products that may be linked to child labour – in pictures
item.description:
On World Day Against Child Labour, we look at everyday items that may involve some of the world’s 168 million child workers in their production processes, from necklaces and smartphones to tea and chocolate

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Charities urge MPs not to cut back on overseas aid spending
item.description:
Heads of 20 top NGOs say UK should be proud of the difference 0.7% of income makes to millions of lives

Some of Britain’s biggest charities are calling on MPs to stick with the country’s commitment to overseas aid, with a major debate on the subject taking place in Westminster on Monday.

Critics say the UK’s aid budget – 0.7% of national income – is too high. But in a letter signed by, among others, the chief executives of Oxfam, the anti-poverty ONE campaign, Marie Stopes International, Unicef UK and Christian Aid, parliamentarians are told Britain should be proud of the impact it has on millions of lives.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Tracy McVeigh

item.title: The Orlando massacre terrorist will fail. Here's why – video
item.description:
Owen Jones argues that the terrorist who carried out America’s worst ever mass shooting in Orlando will fail – just as a neo-Nazi terrorist did 17 years ago in London, when he detonated a nail bomb outside the Admiral Duncan pub in the heart of the capital’s LGBT community

  • On Sky News last night, I realised how far some will go to ignore homophobia
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Owen Jones and Adam Sich

item.title: Orlando shooting exposes so many of America’s faultlines
item.description:
Some politicians will focus on Islam; others on homophobia or gun control. And all will be judged

  • Orlando shooting – live updates

As relatives grieve and a nation mourns, America’s political class will pick through the wreckage of the heinous events in Orlando and try to frame the tragedy in a way that suits their agenda. Those who hoped a tragedy of this nature might be extracted from partisan politics will be sorely disappointed.

Related: ‘Everyone get out and keep running': how the Orlando attack unfolded

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Gary Younge

item.title: Orlando gunman known to FBI shows difficulty of 'lone wolf' cases
item.description:
• Omar Mateen was interviewed and placed under surveillance
  • Connection to Florida man who became suicide bomber was ‘minimal’
  • Obama: attack that killed 50 and injured 53 ‘an act of terror’
  • Opinion: Gay men can’t donate blood to victims. That’s absurd

The mass slaughter at an LGBT nightclub in Orlando was performed by a man known for years to federal law enforcement but whose connections to terrorism were found to be insubstantial, highlighting a vexing problem for counter-terrorism investigators and privacy advocates.

Related: Florida nightclub shooting: 50 killed and 53 injured in 'act of terror' – latest updates

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Spencer Ackerman in New York

item.title: Saudi Arabia's row with Ban Ki-moon over Yemen marks new low in UN relationship
item.description:
Kingdom angry at being criticised for violations of children’s rights in country where it is fighting Houthi rebels

Saudi Arabia has never liked the United Nations, but the spat with Ban Ki-moon over the child casualties of the war in Yemen this week marks a new low.

It was extraordinary to hear the secretary-general admit publicly on Thursday that he had had his arm twisted to change tack in the wake of anger from Riyadh.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ian Black Middle East editor

item.title: Could Hillary Clinton really be indicted over her emails?
item.description:
The FBI is still investigating and while the candidate herself and much expert opinion say it’s not going to happen, any indictment could end her campaign

Did Hillary Clinton do the wrong thing when she used a private email server while secretary of state from 2009 to 2013?

Yes. She herself has admitted that it was a mistake. A recent report by the state department inspector general found that she broke multiple rules despite repeated warnings to use official communications methods that would ensure her emails were stored and kept safe from hackers.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David Smith in Washington

item.title: Opioids are a bipartisan issue because they've become a mainstream, white one | Celine Gounder
item.description:
Our lawmakers don’t agree on much, but they do agree on needing to give more funds to fighting the US painkiller epidemic now that it’s hit white people

In an act of extraordinary bipartisanship, the Senate appropriations committee approved almost doubling funding to fight the opioid epidemic on Thursday, clearing the way for a full Senate vote.

The legislative branch is notable for how polarized it has become during the Obama administration, but Republicans and Democrats come together on opioid abuse prevention and treatment in a way that they haven’t for other issues arguably of equal importance, like Zika or the cancer moonshot. Congress passed the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act (Cara) this spring by an overwhelming majority and, last fall, under the looming threat of HIV and hepatitis outbreaks fueled by injection drug abuse, lawmakers repealed the ban on federal funding for needle exchange programs.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Celine Gounder

item.title: Where Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton stand on 2016's key issues
item.description:
Criminal justice, the economy and immigration have been at the fore of this election cycle. Here are policies expressed by both candidates on those and more

It has been described as the most polarising election in decades, a stark choice between two visions of America. Will Hillary Clinton offer a third term of Barack Obama? Will Donald Trump, as some critics claim, pose a threat to national security? Based on their speeches and websites, here is a rundown of what we know about the candidates’ policies on key issues.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David Smith in Washington

item.title: MI6 gets off scot-free over rendition of suspected Islamists to Libya
item.description:
It seems everyone involved in Belhaj and Saadi affair will escape prosecution, even though it involved torture

So after more than four years of Scotland Yard investigations, and months of agonising within the Crown Prosecution Service, ministers and MI6 are getting off scot-free over the abduction and subsequent torture of two suspected Islamists.

Abdel Hakim Belhaj and Sami al-Saadi were enemies of Muammar Gaddafi delivered to Tripoli, courtesy of MI6 and the CIA, in 2004 when Tony Blair’s government was cuddling up to the Libyan dictator. Gaddafi had promised to abandon his nuclear and chemical weapons programme and as a reward for British friendship – including the secret rendition of his opponents – he agreed to huge and lucrative oil deals for BP.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Richard Norton-Taylor

item.title: The world lights up in tribute to the lives lost in Orlando – in pictures
item.description:
Buildings around the world have been illuminated in rainbow colors to honor the 49 people killed in the nightclub attack and to stand in solidarity with the LGBT community

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gilbert

item.title: Omar Mateen's father says he cannot forgive his son – video
item.description:
The father of Omar Mateen, who shot dead 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, said he was sorry for his son’s actions and does not forgive him. Speaking from his home in Port Saint Lucie, Florida, Seddique Mateen said he was angry and saddened by his son’s violent rampage. ‘Why did he do that to the homeland? Those people who died, they are our family … And the 52 people who got injured, they are our family’

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Orlando gunman Omar Mateen was a regular at Pulse, says nightclubber – video
item.description:
Jim Van Horn, a regular at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida, says Omar Mateen had been to the venue on numerous occasions before Sunday, when he shot dead 49 people. Van Horn says he believes Mateen was gay and had been trying to pick up men

  • Orlando shooter Omar Mateen ‘was a regular at Pulse nightclub’
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Barack Obama: Orlando gunman was radicalised online – video
item.description:
President Barack Obama says Omar Mateen, who killed 49 people at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida, was ‘inspired by extremist information disseminated over the internet’ to carry out the shooting attack. After meeting security officials at the White House on Monday, Obama says there is no evidence that the shooter was ‘directed externally’

  • FBI and Obama confirm Omar Mateen was radicalized on the internet
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Trump renews call for ban on Muslim refugees after Orlando shooting – video
item.description:
Donald Trump on Monday renewed his call for a ban on Muslims coming into the United States in the wake of the Orlando nightclub shooting. Speaking at a rally in New Hampshire, Trump said, ‘We cannot continue to allow thousands upon thousands of people to pour into our country, many of whom have the same thought process of this savage killer’

  • Trump: ‘I will suspend immigration’ from many countries as president – campaign live
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Hillary Clinton on Orlando shooting: we must target extremism 'virus' – video
item.description:
Hillary Clinton on Monday said that although the perpetrator of the mass shooting in Orlando was dead, the ‘virus’ of extremism was still alive. Referring to so-called ‘lone wolf’ attacks, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee said the country was facing a ‘twisted ideology and poisoned psychology’

Continue reading...
